newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian T-bills open firmer amid steady dollar.
newsitem.headline: Canadian T-bills open firmer amid steady dollar.

text.p: Canadian T-bills opened mostly firmer on Friday amid stronger Canadian and U.S. bond markets, steady trade in the Canadian dollar and good interest from accounts, analysts said.

"There's a little bit better tone in U.S. fixed-income markets this morning. And relative to where the Canadian dollar was trading last night it's doing slightly better here this morning," said Doug Sannuto, managing director of Canada cash markets with Bank of Montreal.
Canada's three-month when-issued T-bill firmed to yield 2.99 percent from 3.01 percent at Thursday's close.
"We're seeing some demand from customers this morning," said Sannuto.
Canadian T-bills firmed as the currency strengthened past Thursday's close of C$1.3730 (US$0.7283) after initially beginning the session weaker.
The Canadian money market also benefitted from firmer U.S. Treasuries, which began the session firmer ahead of an early close at 1400 EDT/1800 GMT.
In other prices, the six-month when-issued T-bill firmed to yield 3.34 percent from 3.36 percent. The one-year T-bill firmed to yield 3.71 percent from 3.74 percent.
The call loan rate traded at 2.95 percent, the center of the Bank of Canada's 2.75-3.25 percent target range.
